issues.title: About function
issues.author: yangbodong22011
issues.body:
Functions can be invoked at the tail end of a path - the input to a function is the output of the path expression. The function output is dictated by the function itself.

Refer：https://github.com/json-path/JsonPath#functions

comments.author: gregsdennis
comments.body:
Thank you for this.  This is one possibility for a syntax for functions.  There are others, e.g. the common syntax `foo(param1, param2, ...)`.

We will need to compare all options before we make a decision.

comments.author: yangbodong22011
comments.body: @gregsdennis Yes, MongoDB operator is also a good choice: https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/reference/operator/query/

comments.author: danielaparker
comments.body:
> Functions can be invoked at the tail end of a path - the input to a function is the output of the path expression. The function output is dictated by the function itself.
> 
> Refer：https://github.com/json-path/JsonPath#functions

Many, perhaps most, JSONPath implementations support functions in one form or another, in some cases only in filter expressions, in other cases both in and outside of filter expressions. The former generally restrict JSONPath to selecting elements in the original document only, the latter permit results that are computations performed on the original document.

(1) Implementations that use JavaScript (or Python or PHP) for evaluating JSONPath filter expressions, including original JavaScript Goessner, have access to all the JavaScript (or Python or PHP) functions. For example, they have access to functions that return the Unicode Normalization Form of strings, see [JavaScript String.prototype.normalize](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/String/normalize) (or [Python unicodedata.normalize](https://docs.python.org/3.6/library/unicodedata.html#unicodedata.normalize) or [PHP normalizer.normalize](https://www.php.net/manual/en/normalizer.normalize.php)).

(2) The important and influential [Jayway implementation](https://github.com/json-path/JsonPath) introduced functions that can be invoked at the tail end of the path, as you mentioned. These can be used to return results that are computations performed on the original document.

(3) A couple of implementations that made up their own filter expression languages support function syntax like
```
$.books[?(tokenize(@.author,'\\s+')[-1] == 'Tolkien')]
```
see e.g. [here](https://danielaparker.github.io/JsonCons.Net/articles/JsonPath/JsonConsJsonPath.html#functions).

comments.author: gregsdennis
comments.body:
***NOTE** I definitely think support for functions should **not** be part of the initial release but should be considered for follow-up releases.*

I would like to propose the typical syntax for functions:

```
function_name([param list])
```

- A function name MUST be a string that starts with an alpha char and is followed by any number of alpha-numeric chars and underscores (same character set as `.`-syntax property names).  This should make them easily identifiable in expressions.
- A function MUST have parentheses, even if there are no parameters.
- The parameter list MUST be comma-delimited.  Each parameter may be any valid JSON Path expression, including the constant values that are allowed, e.g. booleans, numbers, etc, but not structured values (unless those are supported by the time functions are implemented).
- A function MUST return a value.

I would also suggest that parameters have an _expected_ type.  If the function receives a value for a parameter that is the wrong type, it should return `false` or some other "negative"-indicating value, much like the existence test.

### Predefined functions to start

#### `length(x)`

Receives any valid JSON Path, probably most commonly `@`, and returns the object or array length of the value at that location.

Optional support:

- non-singular paths - the return value would be the number of results returned by the path.
- string values - the return value would be the string length (probably unicode chars, not byte count)

#### `index()`

Receives no parameters and returns the index / property name of the current item (`@`).  I see no value in attempting to get the key of a specified path.

### Custom function support

Building on this, we could allow for implementations to support user-defined functions, but we'd have to include a statement that user-defined functions would not be expected to be supported the same way or at all in other implementations.

I think this is potentially very powerful as many users use JSON Path simply within their local environment rather than sending paths between systems.

This is something that I would probably support in my implementation (should functions become a syntax) even if it's not supported in the spec.  (Of course, I'd document the interoperability aspects of defining your own functions.)

comments.author: danielaparker
comments.body:
> _**NOTE** I definitely think support for functions should **not** be part of the initial release but should be considered for follow-up releases._
> 
Follow up _releases_, in the plural? Wouldn't that negate the primary benefit of an RFC, which is interoperability? 

> Each parameter may be any valid JSON Path expression, including the constant values that are allowed, e.g. booleans, numbers, etc, but not structured values (unless those are supported by the time functions are implemented).

I understand that in the draft it's currently underspecified what JSONPath expressions can evaluate to, but you're not suggesting that they can't evaluate to JSON arrays and objects in any context, are you? Also, if they can evaluate to `undefined`,  as has been proposed, that needs to be part of the type system supported by functions.

> #### `index()`
> Receives no parameters and returns the index / property name of the current item (`@`). 
> 
That doesn't sound like a function, as conventionally understood. Presumably it would need to receive a 'this' or 'self' parameter to access the "current item". Which would also require an extension to the type system needed to support functions.

comments.author: gregsdennis
comments.body:
> Follow up releases, in the plural?

I don't understand what you're getting at.  I sincerely expect there to be revisions to this document after initial publication.  Why wouldn't there be?  Surely we would want to expand on the feature set.  Otherwise, the spec would never be published.

I worded it that way because I wasn't certain it needed to be the _next_ release.  It could be added into any subsequent release.

> Wouldn't that negate the primary benefit of an RFC, which is interoperability?

How does an RFC imply interoperability?

How does this feature (or multiple versioned releases, maybe?) negate interoperability?  If the spec defines functions, then any implementation of that spec, regardless of language/framework, would also be required to support them as defined.  That's interoperability.

> ... but you're not suggesting that they can't evaluate to JSON arrays and objects in any context, are you?

No, I'm not suggested that.  They can definitely evaluate to arrays and objects.  Any valid value should be able to be passed to a function, but if a function receives a value of a type it's not expecting, it should return a negative result of some kind.  This aligns with the current idea that if a path parses correctly, it should not throw errors upon evaluation.

> if they can evaluate to `undefined`, as has been proposed, that needs to be part of the type system supported by functions.

Yeah.

> That doesn't sound like a function, as conventionally understood.

Why not?  Parameterless functions exist.  I considered using `index(@)`, but then it only makes sense for the parameter to be `@`, so why have it at all?  Not having a parameter means that someone couldn't do `index(@.foo)`, which is a pointless function because it just returns `"foo"`.  Making this a parameterless function makes it hard for users to do things they're not allowed to do or don't make sense.  It already knows that its context is the current item (and the item's parent).  (Presumably, the implementation is iterating through the items in a loop and has access to these things, at which point it can pass that context to whatever implementation it has internally.)

comments.author: danielaparker
comments.body:
> > That doesn't sound like a function, as conventionally understood.
> 
> Why not? Parameterless functions exist.

Can you provide an example? I think a parameter-less function must return a constant.

 > I considered using `index(@)`, 

I don't think that works, if you want `index` to be considered a function like any other. In a JSONPath expression, a bare `@` evaluates to a value, a value that does not carry with it any information about the array index or object member name from whence it came. It is only a value. 

Of course, an implementation could use the _notation_ `index(@)` to represent the index or name associated with `@`, but it would be an ad hoc thing, using information unavailable to your custom function, were it to be passed `@`.  

> Making this a parameterless function makes it hard for users to do things they're not allowed to do or don't make sense. It already knows that its context is the current item (and the item's parent).

In order for the function to "know" anything about its context, it needs to be passed a parameter (possibly hidden) such as "this" in C++ or "self" in Python, or otherwise be bound to an environment. To support that would make a specification for functions much more complicated, certainly beyond that of [JMESPath functions](https://jmespath.org/specification.html#built-in-functions), for example.

comments.author: gregsdennis
comments.body:
Firstly, we're not trying to build a full programming language.  If we were, I might be inclined to agree with you.  But we're trying to build a query syntax, and that affords us some liberties.

I think you're looking at it from a pure-functional point of view.  A pure function would, in most cases, return a constant without any parameters.  But as I said, we're not building a _programming_ language, functional or otherwise.

An example of a parameterless function (in another query language) would be SQL's `DATE()` function, which returns the current date.  It is _defined_ to have the context of the system on which the query is running.  It _never_ returns the same value twice (without adjusting the system or mocking that dependency entirely).

Similarly, the `index()` function could be _defined_ to have the context of the iterator in which it runs, i.e. the filter query `[?()]`.

Since you made a parallel with C++, consider this like a member function that's defined on the iterator itself rather than a static/global function.  Even if you consider `this` as a (hidden) parameter, it doesn't appear as a parameter when you call it ("hidden" 😉);  the parameter list is empty.

`length(x)` acts more like the pure function you're thinking of.  It doesn't need any context; it just acts on the parameter it's given.  But this doesn't mean that `index()` must also work that way.

Lastly, defining `index()` this way opens the door for others functions, and even user-defined functions if we do that, to do similar things, which I think it's extremely useful.  Requiring only pure functions severely inhibits their usefulness.

issues.title: Mention SQL/JSON Path Expression
issues.author: nichtich
issues.body:
**SQL/JSON Path Expression** (as specified in [SQL ISO standard](https://www.iso.org/standard/78937.html)) was heavily inspired by JSONPath, overlaps in both syntax and semantics and has a similar name. I'm sure there is a common subset of both languages, but finding out the exact edge cases and differences would be an unreasonable demand. Anyway, this is and will be source of confusion and subtle bugs in applications that wrongly assume to know which JSON query language they are using.

The JSONPath RFC should at least mention ISO SQL/JSON Path Expression to make clear that its not the same and incompatibilities should be expected when using JSON Path Expressions as JSONPath or the reverse.

cabo
comments.body: We would need to obtain a copy of that document to write something sensible about it.

comments.author: gregsdennis

comments.author: cabo
comments.body:

The answer doesn't have to be right, we just need consensus.
(I do have higher standards for the decisions that influence interoperability, but this one is a toss.)

issues.title: Make @ optional in filter selectors
issues.author: nichtich
issues.body:
The grammar includes `"@"` only it at `rel-path` rule in filter expressions. `rel-path` is only used in rule `path`:

    path         = rel-path / json-path
    rel-path     = "@" *(S (dot-selector / index-selector))

As `json-path` always starts with `$`, a parser does not need the `"@"` to distinguish between `rel-path` and `json-path`, so the character can be made optional, helping JSONPath expressions look less like obfuscated Per (SCNR).

Example:

    $[? @.key>42 && @.key<44 ]
    $[?  .key>42 &&  .key<44 ]

The latter is more readable, isn't it?

comments.author: cabo
comments.body:
We could do this.
Matters of taste aside (I find the version with the @ sign to be more readable), this would be an innovation unless existing implementations already are doing this.
We are not chartered to innovate, except where this is necessary to achieve an interoperable (and evolvable) situation.

comments.author: nichtich
comments.body:
I guess you are accustomed to the `@` so feels natural, but from a usability point of view it is noise and confusing (what's the difference between `@.foo` and `.foo`?  Why is `$.foo` allowed at the root but not `@.foo`?...) *except* when you are already used to it. Making it optional would not break existing JSONPath expressions but it would make existing implementations lack support of a new feature. You decide what weights more: simplicity and usability or keeping existing implementations fully compliant with the spec. As far as I understand, parenthesis in filter expressions (`[?(...)]`) have also been dropped although they were mandatory.

Another argument *against* making `@` optional would be to better align with SQL/JSON Path Expression Syntax.

comments.author: danielaparker
comments.body:
> what's the difference between `@.foo` and `.foo`? 

I don't know of prior experience with bare expressions that omit only the "current node" symbol, but not the dot. But there is plenty outside of JSONPath for omitting _both_ the "current node" symbol and the dot - see [The "current value" or "current node", and the meaning thereof](https://github.com/ietf-wg-jsonpath/draft-ietf-jsonpath-base/issues/76). That's the case for JMESPath and XPath. SQL also permits omitting qualifying table names or aliases when there is no ambiguity.

Allowing `foo` in place of `@.foo` does mean that unquoted names should not be allowed to start with a digit, otherwise expressions like `$foo[?(2 == 4)]` would be ambiguous. There is some data about that [here](https://cburgmer.github.io/json-path-comparison/results/filter_expression_with_dot_notation_with_number.html), a minority of JSONPath implementations do allow unquoted names that start with a digit, as did earlier versions of the draft. But it looks like recent versions of the draft do not, so could accommodate your proposal.

> Why is `$.foo` allowed at the root but not `@.foo`?

That's a good question. There was a [proposal by Davide Bettio](https://github.com/ietf-wg-jsonpath/draft-ietf-jsonpath-base/issues/59) to support `@.foo` at the root, and it was discussed at the [May 2021 ietf meeting](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/minutes-interim-2021-jsonpath-01-202105110900/). The proposal was dismissed with the "consensus" that "Queries should not begin with @, but this is a natural extension point."

It's not obvious from reading the minutes that the committee fully understood that not accomodating JSONPath expressions beginning with `@` was tantamount to asserting that expressions in filters beginning with `@` were not JSONPath expressions (unfortunately Bettio was not present to defend the proposal.) In any case, it's clear in the draft that they are not, the draft defines them as
```
rel-path     = "@" *(S (dot-selector / index-selector))
```

In terms of prior experience, implementations (at least the important ones) group into two categories.

(1) Implementations including original JavaScript Goessner that use JavaScript (or Python or PHP) for evaluating JSONPath filter expressions. In these scripts, `@` is substituted with the "current value", and expressions consisting of the "current value" followed by a dot or a left square bracket are evaluated according to JavaScript (or Python or PHP) rules. This always result in a single value. 

(2) JSONPath implementations that make up their own expression languages.  The important ones (Java Jayway, JSON.Net), regard expressions starting with `@` as JSONPath expressions in their own right, and evaluate them as such. They specify rules for evaluating them as a single value (rather than a list of values) so that evaluations and JSON literals can be meaningfully compared.

The draft authors chose to follow the second group by inventing their own expression language, but the first group by making expressions beginning with `@` somewhat analogous to evaluating JavaScript variables with index and identifier operators. It's unclear to me why they made that choice. I think it would be helpful if they included some notes in the draft to motivate their decisions in terms of prior experience.

issues.title: Specify handing of null
issues.author: glyn
issues.body:
The current spec is silent about how `null` is handled in many situations:

1. What is the result of applying the JSONPath `$` to the JSON document `null`?
2. What is the result of applying the JSONPath `$.*` to the JSON document `{"a": null}`? The [comparison consensus](https://cburgmer.github.io/json-path-comparison/results/dot_notation_on_null_value.html) implies a node set with the single value `null`.
3. What is the result of applying the JSONPath `$[*]` to the JSON document `[null]`? The [comparison consensus](https://cburgmer.github.io/json-path-comparison/results/bracket_notation_with_wildcard_on_null_value_array.html) implies a node set with the single value `null`.
4. What is the result of applying the JSONPath `$[0]` to the JSON document `[null]`? Presumably a node set with the single value `null`.
5. What is the result of applying the JSONPath `$[1:2]` to the JSON document `["a", null, "b"]`? Presumably a node set with the values `"a"` and `null`.
6. What is the result of applying the JSONPath `$[?@]` to the JSON document `["a", null, "b"]`?
7. What is the result of applying the JSONPath `$[?@.a]` to the JSON document `[{"a": null}]`?
8. What is the result of applying the JSONPath `$.null` to the JSON document `{"null": "value"}`? The [comparison consensus](https://cburgmer.github.io/json-path-comparison/results/dot_notation_with_key_named_null.html) implies a node set with the single value `"value"`.

issues.title: Proposal: Value type-checks
issues.author: gregsdennis
issues.body:
***NOTE** I definitely think support for this proposal should **not** be part of the initial release but should be considered for follow-up releases.  I had the idea and wanted to document it.*

## Scenario

Given the following JSON

```json
[
  "foo",
  5,
  { "bar": null },
  "baz",
  null
]
```

there is no way to isolate only string values.

## Proposal

To address this, we should introduce a type check.

I would like to propose the `is` operator for JSON Path expressions in the filter selector `[?()]`.  Examples of usage would be:

```
@ is boolean
@ is string
@ is number
@.foo is object
```

To support this, we would need to reserve `object`, `array`, `boolean`, `number`, `null`, and `string` as reserved keywords in expressions, meaning that functions could not bear these names.  I don't think that this would cause any problems.

It could also support value coercion on the RHS.  For example `@ is $.foo`, could return `true` if `$.foo` is a string containing one of these type keywords.

## A sub-par alternative

I had also considered a `type(x)` function to build on [my proposal for functions](https://github.com/ietf-wg-jsonpath/draft-ietf-jsonpath-base/issues/160#issuecomment-1069549608).

The `type(x)` function would take a single parameter and return... well that's the problem.  What would it return?  It can't rightly return a string.  It would have to return some implementation-internal concept of a "value type", and then we'd have to add support for equality.

`type(@) == object` and `type(@) == "object"` just don't feel right.

I think the `is` operator is the way to go for this feature.

comments.author: cabo
comments.body: A function syntax would have the advantage that it could use an extension point, while new syntax such as " is " always would lead to harder to manage syntax errors.

comments.author: gregsdennis
comments.body:
> A function syntax would have the advantage that it could use an extension point, while new syntax such as " is " always would lead to harder to manage syntax errors.


I'm not sure why `is` would be any harder to parse than any other equivalence operator, e.g. `==` or `!=`.

And again, what would a function return?  How would you test that a value is, for example, an array?

issues.title: Descendant semantics
issues.author: bram209
issues.body:
### Dot Wildcard Selector
> A dot-wild-selector acts as a wildcard by selecting the nodes of all member values of an object in its input nodelist as well as all element nodes of an array in its input nodelist.

Considering the following input:
```json
{
  "o": {"j": 1, "k": 2},
  "a": [5, 3]
}
```

`$.*` would evaluate to (in this case the values of the object):

```json
[
  {"j": 1, "k": 2},
  [5, 3]
]
```

### Descendant Selector

I would expect the descendant version: `$..*` to evaluate to:
```json
[
  {"j": 1, "k": 2},
  [5, 3],
  1,
  2,
  5,
  3
]
```

Yet the example says:
```json
[
  { "o": {"j": 1, "k": 2}, "a": [5, 3] }, // full input is selected, even tho the dot wildcard selector would only select the object values
  {"j": 1, "k": 2},
  [5, 3],
  1,
  2,
  5,
  3
]
```
Considering the following pseudo logic:
```
function traverse(json_value, child_selector) {
     if (json_value == array) {
          return child_selector.select(json_value) + json_value.map(x => traverse(x, child_selector));
    } else if (json_value == object) {
          return child_selector.select(json_value) + json_value.values.map(x => traverse(x, child_selector));
   } else {
         return [];
   }
}
```

In the case of `$..*` the `child_selector` would be an index wildcard selector.

### Expected Descendant semantics
I would expect the descendant selector to (starting by selecting itself) walk through the json structure and select all the results by applying the child selector (dot-member-name, index-selector, index-wild-selector, or wildcard) on each traversed value.

Am I misunderstanding something here or is this the intended behavior?

comments.author: glyn
comments.body:
Thanks for raising this. When I was writing the example, I noticed that only a few implementations included the node itself. But the descendant selector semantics currently say:
> The descendant-selector selects the node and all its descendants.

and so I included the "starting" node itself. This is why I included the following text in the commit message:

> [Note] that contrary to the consensus of the comparison project (below), the root node appears in the results of $..* and $..[*].
> 
>    https://cburgmer.github.io/json-path-comparison/results/dot_notation_with_wildcard_after_recursive_descent.html

The semantics section needs improving anyway to clarify the semantics of the various forms of the descendants selector. I agree with the semantics proposed above, providing there is a consensus for this in the WG.

comments.author: goessner
comments.body:
In my understanding descendant selector `$..*` simply extends the single-level operating of child selector `$.*` , in that it further recursively operates on all other descendant levels.

So I agree to Bram's traversal algorithm above.

A node is not considered a descendant of itself. Obviously I have not been aware of this behavior.

issues.title: Filter expressions: confusing 'exists' semantics
issues.author: bram209
issues.body:
Considering that, according to the grammar, `exist-expr` is a `boolean-exrp`:

```
exist-expr        = [neg-op S] singular-path 
```

And the following note:
> A member or element value by itself in a Boolean context is interpreted as false only if it does not exist. Otherwise it is interpreted as true. To be more specific about the actual value, explicit comparisons are necessary. This existence test -- as an exception to the general rule -- also works with structured values.

So this would mean that a singular path that points to a boolean `false` value would evaluate to `true`.

```json
[
   { "id": 1, "isActive": true },
   { "id": 2, "isActive": false },
   { "id": 3, "isActive": true },
]
```
People might try:
`$[?(@.isActive)]` to get the active elements but will be surprised to see all elements returned.

I think this kind of query is quite common and for people with a developer background it would feel unnatural to type `boolean expression == true`

On the other side,  the need for queries that check *implicitly* for existence feels rarer to me (from my experience mostly well-typed tagged unions are used to structure JSON), which makes me wonder if `exists` should be a function instead (once functions get added to the spec).

This would make the `exists` check more explicit and therefore less confusing, in my opinion.

### Proposed solution
Personally, I would like to:
- have an explicit way of checking existence.
- evaluate singular path to a boolean value (which could be seen as a tautological statement) in the above example

When a singular path is given as a boolean expression but does not point to a boolean value, it gets a bit tricky:
- it could throw an error at the evaluation
- evaluate to false always
- introduce the concept of truthy & falsy values, which could serve similar use cases as `exists`, in this case, `true` would be `truthy` and `false` would be falsy and the above described problem would go away

I normally am more a statically typed programming language guy so not too keen on the concept of truthy & falsy values, but considering this is a query language for JSON, it might make more sense...


Thoughts?

comments.author: bram209
comments.body:
another possibility (that does not rely on functions) is to introduce a new primitive value `undefined` so one would type:
`$[?(@.prop != undefined)]`

comments.author: glyn
comments.body: Unfortunately, there isn't much of a consensus among implementations: [comparison project example](https://cburgmer.github.io/json-path-comparison/results/filter_expression_with_value.html).

comments.author: cabo
comments.body:
In a statically typed language with a Boolean-typed variable `x`,

```
if x == true {...}
```

definitely is a code smell, usually outing a complete noob.

But this isn't a statically typed language with a Boolean type.
(JSON is schema-free and thus dynamically typed, and there is nothing that even justifies the introduction of RFC 8259 to mention "booleans" (sic); the [actual definition](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc8259#section-3) only knows the three separate and independent values false, null, and true.)

comments.author: gregsdennis
comments.body:
> JSON is schema-free and thus dynamically typed

This is just wrong.  _Javascript_ is dynamically typed because it considers objects with different property sets to be different types.  _JSON_ is statically typed: objects, arrays, strings, numbers, and the constants `true`, `false`, and `null`.  (Practically speaking, `true` and `false` are booleans.  Making this distinction is splitting hairs and not worth our time.)  For JSON, objects with different property sets, while they are not equivalent, are still the same type: `object`.

> introduce a new primitive value `undefined`...

We've had plenty of conversations stating that we don't want to introduce `undefined` as a value.  To reiterate the above, JSON isn't Javascript; there is no `undefined` in JSON.

> `if x == true {...}` definitely is a code smell

Agreed, but the point of the argument is that for the expression `!x`, `x` _appears_ to represent some boolean-ish value, and then the `!` operator is negating that result.

We also have declared that expressions in filter selectors (`[?(<expr>)]`) must return boolean values.

This results in a syntactical ambiguity for `[?(!@.foo)]`:

- Is the user testing for the existence of a property?
- Is the user testing for the "truthiness" of the value at that property?

The _only_ way to know for sure is by forcing `!` followed by a local path (e.g. `!@.foo`) to mean an existence test, which means the _only_ way to check for "truthiness" is to compare with a `true` or `false` constant.

For what it's worth, my implementation, https://json-everything.net/json-path, returns all three items for the example above, acting as a true existence test.  This means that for my library, you MUST use `x == true` to only get the "truthy" ones.

---

To summarize, I see two options to resolve this ambiguity:

1. An expression in the form `!@.foo` is defined explicitly as an existence test, which forces path authors to use expressions like `x == true` for "truthiness" checks (would return three items from the above example).
2. Expressions strictly return booleans except in the special case of `!@.foo`, for which the expression is "truthy" or "falsy."  This forces some other form of existence test, e.g. a function form like `exists(@.foo)` (would return two items from the above example).

***NOTE** We've also discussed truthiness at length, and if I recall, we decided against it.  I use it here solely to illustrate my point.*

This gets syntax errors out of the way "early" (i.e. before any JSON documents are encountered) and allows "compilation" of the JSONPath to be performed once before the compiled version is used, possibly many times, to search JSON documents.
* a method on the JSONPath type which takes a _parsed_ form of a JSON document and which returns the search results or an error.

But you've identified a mistake there. Such implementations will _never_ encounter a syntactically invalid JSON document, so they needn't worry about how to handle syntax errors.

So I'm now leaning towards a stricter requirement:
> If a syntactically invalid JSON document is provided, an implementation MUST return an error.

WDYT?

Yes, I was trying to avoid describing `$` as a matcher for the reason you point out. I guess saying that `$` _matches_ the root node gives the impression that `$` is a matcher (regardless of what the ABNF might say). Can you think of a better wording? If not, I'll try again...

> Maybe it's better to define `$` and `@` as _selectors_ and a JsonPath query as selector, followed by matchers sequence (possibly empty)?

I was trying to stick pretty closely to the Proposal A grammar. Also, we need to prevent `@` at the start of a JSONPatth. But your point is well made and will come in useful once we get to filters. Do we really need to do more right now?
Yes, I think that's better.

> we need to prevent @ at the start of a JSONPath

In fact, we do not. Semantic of `@` is "current node", and current node at the start of JsonPath is obviously a root node, so there's no practical reason to avoid `@` at start.

But it's, I'd say, a brave movement and should be discussed more thoroughly. For now, I believe, it's enough to choose between "sequence of matchers" and "selector followed by optional sequence of matchers".

Ok. I'm now wondering how strict to be about checking the JSON document syntax because it's not really the prime responsibility of a JSONPath implementation. In particular, I don't want to over-burden JSONPath implementations in languages which happen to have imperfect JSON parsing libraries. So how about we weaken the wording to:
> If a syntactically invalid JSON document is provided, any implementation SHOULD return an error.

?

I'd like us to adopt an approach for the first version of the internet draft of avoiding new constructs whenever possible as that will increase the migration cost for existing implementations and users. So I think in this PR we should stick with `$` followed by a possibly empty sequence of matchers. I'll reword the above text to avoid calling `$` a matcher and use the "selector" terminology instead, which we can then piggy-back upon nicely when we come to filters. Let me draft that and push the change for your perusal.

Well, in fact many implementations will work without JSON text itself, using the result of JSON parsing as a structure; or even without JSON at all (yaml, for example). XML has DOM, that allows to isolate document structure from text source (and syntax); JSON lacks such tool.

Maybe we should just define JSON data structure as a tree in terms of typed and (partially) ordered nodes, thus totally isolating JsonPath from JSON parsing issues; but for now SHOULD is fairly enough.

> avoiding new constructs whenever possible

That's not a problem - we can define selectors with the following grammar:

```
selector       = root_selector / other_selector
root_selector  = "$"
other_selector = "@"
```

And then define queries like this, avoiding:

```
root_path   = root_selector [ matcher_list ]
filter_path = selector [ matcher_list ]
```

It's not the concrete grammar proposal, just showing an idea how to forbid `@` at the start of outer path.
Thanks @remorhaz. I've used just what we need of this for the moment. I adopted the convention from the ABNF RFC of spelling compound grammar elements using "-" rather than "_".

comments.body:
> by at least one of the union

It is a question if union should "merge" union results or "concatenate" the results. We [have a consensus](https://cburgmer.github.io/json-path-comparison/results/union_with_numbers_in_decreasing_order.html) for reverse ordered indexes, that shows us that we should define the order of merge/concatenation; but the situation of fetching the same index twice (like `$[1,1]`) is still not investigated.

But this question can be discussed later.

Maybe this one should refer to JSON string definition as of [RFC 8259.7](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc8259#section-7)? Otherwise we can get duplicated non-terminals if we allow JSON structures in filters.

But it's a complex question and probably should be discussed separately.
Probably slash omitted after `5B`?
Probably "as described"?

Maybe it's better to fully describe the unescaping process at the beginning of the section without splitting it with matching description? So that at first we describe how do we _get_ the key and then - how we _use_ the key.
Once again, maybe it's better to refer to JSON standard that [defines](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc8259#section-6) `int` non-terminal?
Maybe we should avoid defining index at all and rather consider it as a special case of a slice (when onbly start index is given)?

> It does not match

Maybe `it MUST not match`?
@remorhaz I suggest you raise an issue on this so we don't forget it.
Nice catch.

Actually, I'm inclined to switch to RFC 8259 syntax for strings for consistency alone. But I think we need to allow for single-quoted as well as double-quoted strings, for example like this:
```
union-child = %x22 *double-quoted %x22 / ; "string"
              %x27 *single-quoted %x27   ; 'string'

double-quoted = dq-unescaped /
          escape (
              %x22 /          ; "    quotation mark  U+0022
              %x5C /          ; \    reverse solidus U+005C
              %x2F /          ; /    solidus         U+002F
              %x62 /          ; b    backspace       U+0008
              %x66 /          ; f    form feed       U+000C
              %x6E /          ; n    line feed       U+000A
              %x72 /          ; r    carriage return U+000D
              %x74 /          ; t    tab             U+0009
              %x75 4HEXDIG )  ; uXXXX                U+XXXX


      dq-unescaped = %x20-21 / %x23-5B / %x5D-10FFFF

single-quoted = sq-unescaped /
          escape (
              %x27 /          ; '    apostrophe      U+0027
              %x5C /          ; \    reverse solidus U+005C
              %x2F /          ; /    solidus         U+002F
              %x62 /          ; b    backspace       U+0008
              %x66 /          ; f    form feed       U+000C
              %x6E /          ; n    line feed       U+000A
              %x72 /          ; r    carriage return U+000D
              %x74 /          ; t    tab             U+0009
              %x75 4HEXDIG )  ; uXXXX                U+XXXX

      sq-unescaped = %x20-26 / %x28-5B / %x5D-10FFFF

escape = %x5C                 ; \
```
@cburgmer this is the first time we would be deviating from the syntax in Proposal A. WDYT?
Yes.
Good idea.
Agreed, although I think the syntaxes are equivalent in this case.

I wanted to follow Proposal A and keep the grammar productions for index and slice separate because that approach neatly avoids some the issues by distinguishing between union elements which can select multiple elements and those which can select at most one element. But we may be able to organise the document to keep these definitions close to each other.
Probably. I haven't been consistent in applying MUST etc. and it would certainly be an improvement.

> I think we need to allow for single-quoted as well as double-quoted strings

Of course, but that can be done like this:
```
union-child = %x27 *single-quoted %x27 /  ; 'string'
              json-string ; see RFC blah-blah-blah
```
I mean, JSON string already includes double-quotes in its definition.

I think it would be better to keep the ABNF self-contained:
- It's easier to read without jumping over to another RFC. (We could make the production names the same if that helps and have a comment "copied from RFC nnnn")
- I'd like our text to be immutable, but the ABNF in another RFC could mutate because of errata (which we wouldn't _necessarily_ want to adopt, at least not without our own errata)
- it should be possible to extract the ABNF and generate a lexer/parser from it.
@cabo Have you any general advice about whether it is best to inline or refer to ABNF from existing RFCs?

Funny, I just answered the same question on a different list :-)

Generally, right now, it is better to copy, because there is no actionable way to refer.
Until that get's unwieldy, so if you need the date-time production from RFC 3339, that carries so much baggage you'd better refer.

We are solving the same problem for CDDL right now in the CBOR WG, so maybe we'll have something that will spill over to ABNF as wel.  For now, copy over refer, I'd say.
I'm going to stick with the copy of the ABNF and also preserve the symmetry between single and double quoted strings as I think that's a lot more readable.
I'm going to fix this in a later PR by making a pass through the the whole document.
Actually, I've decided not to change this because the JSON standard doesn't provide a suitable signed integer production. We can revisit this when float literals make their appearance.

comments.author: glyn
comments.body: @cabo fyi I still need to make an editorial pass to use the terms MUST, SHOULD, etc. consistently. But you may care to skim read this version to get a feel for where we are at.

I suggest breaking this into two sentences. "A syntactically valid matcher MUST NOT produce errors. This means that some operations which might be considered erroneous, such as indexing beyond the end of an array, result in fewer descendants being selected".
I found this difficult to follow. Perhaps something like "Array access is a union element which matches zero or more elements of an array node."
Same comment as above, this is a little difficult for me to follow.
Should "does not match a node which is not an array" appear at the top of the section with the introduction about Array Access?
Yes, I like that thanks.
Expression like `$[0, 1]` will not be included in the spec?

I'm using the terminology of a matcher _matching_ a node and then _selecting_ subnodes. There's a clear distinction for example with "dot child" where the key matches the key in an object but the matcher selects the value subnode. In the array case, we can probably get away with shortening this. Let's see how that pans out.

Yes. I was trying to avoid duplication in the syntax and semantics section, but I think it reads better with a bit of repetition.

When my wife was a maths teacher, she used to tell me "You only learn by repetition. You only learn by repetition."
Tried a rewording. See what you think.
Yes it will. According to the syntax definition `[0, 1]` is a union of two array accesses.
Oh, my fault,  index access is a type of union element, sorry.

No problem. If others make the same mistake, we may need to think about how to address that in the document.

(I am trying to avoid adding numerous examples, which might be one fix, as that can weaken a standards document because less attention is paid to the normative text, by both readers and authors.)

> zero or more descendants of the node

Are we sure we're not going to allow nodes from input list to get included in the output list (like `descendant-or-self::` axis in XPath)?

Ah, I think you missed the following in the Terminology section 2.2:
> The descendants of a node are taken to include the node itself and the descendants of any children of the node.
Maybe we should define the last element of array as `{"c":2}` - just to demonstrate how non-matching node is filtered out?

> result is the concatenation

I think we should explicitly define here (or somewhere else) what happens when concatenated lists contain same node (we have unions, so it's absolutely possible).

> it MUST be non-zero

I'm not sure if we should make zero step illegal; maybe it's better to define that array-slice with zero step just matches nothing? I don't feel that this situation is worth complicationg syntax / throwing a syntax error; it's just like selecting an index out of range - so why we would want to especially handle this situation?

Another argument is query templates: user may use something like `sprintf("$.a[%d:%d:%d]", x, y, z)` and it may be quite surprising to get syntax errors on zero `z` and not getting it on any other value.
Yep. But in this case it seems that the term "descendant" doesn't fit very well. What would you think about replacing it with "branch"?

I don't follow why "descendant" doesn't fit well. Please could you elaborate?

("branch" seems like a strange term, unless you have a particular definition in mind.)

I mean, when I say "descendant" I usually mean direct or indirect child of a node, but not the node itself. I'm not a native English-speaker and thus I may be wrong, but I don't feel that node can be "a descendant of itself". XPath also separates "descendant-or-self" from "descendant" semantically.

Branch is, of course, not a good variant too.
Yes: changed to allow zero.
Added.
I'll add a placeholder for now. Do you happen to know if there's a consensus on this?
Yes, I take your point. It's too risky to redefine the normal meaning of descendant as people could miss, or forget, the redefinition. I'll try rewording this.
Done. See what you think.
In fact, there are three lists concatenated: two of length one and one of length zero.
Good catch. Fixed.

comments.body: Ticket raised against xml2rfc: https://trac.tools.ietf.org/tools/xml2rfc/trac/ticket/553.
I _quite_ like being able to use a quoted key to specify a dot child name, but is there a precedent or consensus for this? I've tried to avoid innovation as much as possible in this version.
I'm trying to make this document self-contained, so please could you add definitions for `DIGIT` and `ALPHA`? In particular, it should be possible to extract the ABNF and then generate a parser.
I'm not convinced this should include surrogates such as `D800`.
"defined below" is a bit risky. Best to describe and link to the specific section.

Well, what I see now is: the majority of implementations support the syntax itself (so we should support it, too, I believe). But there's a difference in a way of decoding the key: some implementations consider quotes as non-special part of the ID ("raw" approach) and some "unquote" the string. The following links show that there's no clear "majority" in the approach, but I think that "unquote" approach is much less surprising than "raw" one.

https://cburgmer.github.io/json-path-comparison/results/dot_notation_with_double_quotes.html
https://cburgmer.github.io/json-path-comparison/results/dot_notation_with_single_quotes.html

`DIGIT` and `ALFA` are defined in [appendix B.1 of ABNF RFC](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5234#appendix-B.1), and they are widely used in other RFCs without re-defining. For example, [JSON RFC](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc8259#section-6) uses `DIGIT` rule as a part of JSON number definition.
Maybe it's better to move the definition itself up, so the reader have no need to jump to it while reading from the beginning?

I agree that we could adopt that approach, but as we've discussed elsewhere, there isn't a formal way to pull in ABNF definitions from an RFC, so this introduces a formal weakness which I'd personally prefer to avoid.

It's tricky because either way could be surprising. If we adopt the "unquote" approach, then why bother having bracket child notation at all? It would really be superfluous. I'd find that surprising.

Also, both Gössner's implementations adopt the "raw" approach and I feel that we should probably use Gössner to break any "ties" now that we are going to merge into an internet draft which will include him as an author.

I just follow the philosophy of JSON strings here. [Section 7 of JSON RFC](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc8259#section-7) defines non-ASCII range as "continuum" of codepoints within Unicode range, and [section 8.2](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc8259#section-8.2) explicitly describes the surrogate case.
Seems reasonable. Why not try that and see if it works out?
I really like following JSON string syntax. Since it's an area that will be debated again, I think it would be worth adding some text to this document (like the comment above) to call that out.
Okay, I see no problem in redefining some core ABNF rules that we use, I'll do that.
Thanks!

> If we adopt the "unquote" approach, then why bother having bracket child notation at all?

Interesting point, very good. But on the other hand, we have no "bracket child" anymore: brackets define union now (and the former "bracket child" is just a special case of singular union) - that's the main reason for having them, I believe.

I feel that if both interpretations are surprising, then we should probably forbid the quotes in dot-child-name at all, bringing some existing queries as a sacrifice to clarity. What do you think?
That seems reasonable to me and it's consistent with the definition of `unquoted-key` which already prohibits single and double quotes from appearing anywhere.
We don't need to do that anymore, because we've rejected supporting quoted dot-child-names.
I think it would be neater to define separate rules for `DIGIT` and `ALPHA`. Then we could probably do without the "core ABNF" comments, which are slightly distracting for the general reader.
Done!

This text is similar to that in [RFC 7159 section 8.2](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7159#section-8.2), but our goal is slightly different. RFC 7159 defined the JSON data format whereas we are defining a standard for JSONPath implementations. So we should probably say something about implementations rather than the more general "software". How about the following (which also has some editorial improvements)?
```suggestion
                  <t>Note that the <tt>dot-child-name</tt> rule follows the philosophy of JSON strings and is
                     allowed to contain bit sequences that cannot encode Unicode characters (a single unpaired UTF-16 surrogate, for example).
                     The behaviour of an implementation is undefined for child names which do not encode Unicode characters.
```

comments.author: gregsdennis
comments.body: No.  Stop talking about actual values. We shouldn't be doing that. We should define ***behavior***, not limits. Limits are an implementation detail. What happens when those limits are exceeded is for us to define.

comments.author: glyn
comments.body:
> No. Stop talking about actual values. We shouldn't be doing that. We should define _**behavior**_, not limits. Limits are an implementation detail. What happens when those limits are exceeded is for us to define.

Yes, I have some sympathy for this. From a spec point of view, we should either get correct slice behaviour or an error (still to be mentioned in the text). Implementations which choose poor limits will soon get an appropriate reputation.

This is somewhat analogous to specifying `malloc` non-deterministically: it either succeeds or it fails, but we don't try to say when it will fail as that would get into implementation detail.

comments.author: mkmik
comments.body:
Javascript's `.slice` method has the same semantics w.r.t the negative indices and behaviour w.r.t out of bound indices, but it lacks a `step`. Which is good because the JSON in JSONPath has a historical connection with JS. Should we mention that the core slicing syntax (excluding the step part) is based on JavaScript semantics?

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_programming_languages_(array) may not be exhaustive but shows that python is the only language that has inclusive start, exclusive end and a step.

The "python connection" thus comes into play only once we introduce `step`. If we want to support `step` (not sure if we have to), then I think it would be quite confusing if the behaviour of JSONPath were different than the only other (popular) language that has the `first:end:step` syntax.

Whether the spec should explicitly acknowledge this connection is another question. One one hand it would be weird to not acknowledge it, but on the other hand, what if the spec ends up being subtly different from python's? is there an unambiguous spec of the slicing expression for python or is it de-facto implementation defined?

Perhaps a signed 32 bit range could be mandatory (MUST) and a signed 64 bit range recommended (SHOULD).

SGTM, w.r.t array length.

What about slice start and end positions? The RI offers an API that allows for full 64-bit absolute range *and* a full 64-bit range for "end relative" positions. If "end relative" positions are "naively" implemented with negative numbers (as suggested by the standard's own syntactic layer), that would limit implementations to only 63 bits to specify an absolute position (the same problem arises for those implementations that choose a 32-bit index space, and use 31-bit signed positions).

On balance, I'd prefer to keep the spec simple rather than complicate it for "non-naive" implementations. Signed 64 bit values of slice start and end positions should be fine for all real-world JSON arrays. Implementations that choose to support only signed 32 bit values could be at a disadvantage for very large JSON arrays, but in that case, it would probably be better to use an implementation that supports signed 64 bit values.

for paths input to a JSONPath processor.  Bracket–notation is more general than dot-notation and can serve as a canonical form when a JSONPath processor uses JSONPath expressions for internal purposes or as output paths

I'm in two minds. One of the main advantages of targeting the jsonpath specification at describing how an engine produces a sequence of _output paths_ as opposed to a sequence of _values_, is that it actually simplifies discussing about what a "value" actually is and removes potential causes of confusion that may arise in case an engine uses a compressed representation of a json tree, e.g. one where repeated subtrees may be actually reused.

Referencing Pointer is good, but I wonder if we can do more. The purposes of the two syntaxes are different.  Pointer is for isolating a single location within a document. Path is a query syntax which pulls multiple locations.
Why not just use Pointer?  It's specifically designed for isolating a single location, well-defined, and widely supported.
To @mkmik's point, defining a "value" as also the location from where it was obtained progresses toward defining the duplicates question.

Your suggestions still mention "internal purposes."  I think this needs to be left out entirely.  My implementation doesn't use any notation internally; I have a data model.

This spec shouldn't concern itself with the internal working of implementations.  It should be more of a functional requirement set.  As long as it gives the expected output, it should be compliant, regardless of how it got there.  (This isn't high school algebra where you have to show your work.)
Avoiding the underlying scripting language is good, but it means that we'll have to eventually define what's valid in expressions. (Can of worms, I know.)
JSON objects are specifically unordered, and many languages simply _can't_ reference them in the serialized sequence (Ruby comes to mind.)  We went over and over this recently in JSON Schema.

The wording her certainly can be improved.  The existing text tries to emphasize that array indices start at 1 in XPath and at 0 in JSONPath, it certainly is not trying to invent numeric indices for maps (JSON objects).

Thanks for a good set of actionable proposals for improvement!  I'll submit an update on Wednesday.

I'd like to get terminology nailed down sooner rather than later, but it doesn't have to be part of this PR.

Specifically, JSON Schema uses JSON Pointers in its `$ref` keyword to reference a location within the schema in its JSON form.  Per JSON Schema, the reference MUST resolve to a valid schema object.  However, `{}` is a perfectly valid object.

The only time Section 7 applies is when the pointer indicates a route _into_ this object, e.g. `/a/missing` in @cabo's example would be required to error because the value at `/a` doesn't contain a `missing` property.

RFC 6901 goes to lengths to make sure any JSON map key (which essentially is any Unicode string) can be used as a path component.  It decodes that (needing an escape for / and then for the escape), and then looks whether it is looking at an array or a map.  Any maps is directly indexed, while for an array the path component is interpreted as a decimal number (there also is the "-" special, which I think we don't need).  The latter is easy.  Doing the former requires having a bracket/string syntax for any Unicode string.

Please see my [comment](https://github.com/ietf-wg-jsonpath/draft-ietf-jsonpath-jsonpath/issues/60#issuecomment-801313287).  Also @danielaparker's [comment](https://github.com/ietf-wg-jsonpath/draft-ietf-jsonpath-jsonpath/issues/74#issuecomment-801142162) regarding "JSON in, JSON out."

I have reread both comments now.

Yeah, so my point of having you reread those comments was to illustrate my discomfort with the "nodelist" concept.  You have neither refuted those comments nor changed the PR, so this remains unresolved.
Where is that definition? Would it not make sense to define it in... the definitions section?

Some discussion about nodelist has happened.  Right now, the discussion in this WG is a bit fragmented; I'll try to dig this out when I have time to search for it.  Should have pointed to it in the first place...

The normalization we already have is in Section 3.6.2.4 (it is not about output paths, btw.)
I don't think that needs to be in the definitions, as it is local to that section.  That would probably also be the case when text about the normalization is written that leads to Output Paths.

Just to note, I share with @gregsdennis some discomfort with the "nodelist" concept, and am skeptical that it's needed to describe JSONPath. I don't think the idea of a "nodelist" is required to describe the distinguishing feature of JSONPath, that it returns a collection of values (or references) to items that already exist in the original JSON document. We have from the [very beginning](https://goessner.net/articles/JsonPath/) the notion that "the return value of jsonPath is an array, which is also a valid JSON structure. So you might want to apply jsonPath to the resulting structure". Practically all implementations support something like:
```
JSON = jsonPath(JSON, path, value option)    
```
or 
```
JSON = jsonPath(JSON, path, path option)
```
With duplicates allowed, which is the case for legacy implementations, the computational model is simply to collect values (or their associated paths). Where is the role for "nodelists"?

With no duplicates, which is the case for some modern implementations, the computational model is to compute both values and their associated (normalized) paths, and to keep path-value pairs with unique paths. Again, where is the role for "nodelists"?

In XPath, with it's vastly more complicated data model, I understand the need for "nodelist". But I don't understand why we need to take this XPath idea and transpose it to JSONPath. It seems to me to be an unnecessary concept for describing JSONPath.

I would also suggest that the draft  isn't clear about what it means by "node". In a discussion in the terminology issue, @glyn suggested that if I wasn't familiar with trees and nodes, I could consult Wikipedia. But what's important is not what I understand or don't understand, what's important is what the draft says. In XPath specifications, the meaning of "node" is crystal clear, in the draft, it is not. I think that lack of clarity is somewhat related to the problem of making an argument for the "nodelist" concept that readers such as myself might find convincing.

I think there should be an issue raised for "nodelist, and the justification thereof".  Perhaps @cabo could start one?
I prefer non-negative for the reason @gregsdennis gave.

comments.body: I changed this as requested.
My first reaction has been in favor of "unsigned". But @gregsdennis' "storage related" argument definitly is a point for "non-negative" ... agreed.

Actually, I made this change because I don't really care too much, but I don't agree with it at all.

People are using unsigned type because they care about the application data type (which is unsigned), only rarely because the bits are then laid out in a specific way.

There is a long history of computer languages struggling with naming unsigned types.  FORTRAN only had INTEGER, which was signed.  In the 1970s, languages started to address the issue, but didn't find terminology that they could use from mathematics.  "Natural" is both (1..) and (0..) in common usage, so it is ambiguous.  A number of languages used "Cardinal" for unsigned integers.  C led the pack with going for "unsigned", and that is the term that has stuck.  But, incredibly, as late as the mid 1990s languages were designed that didn't have unsigned types (e.g., Java).

To me, requiring the clumsy term "non-negative" for unsigned is a bit like requiring to say "octet" for byte, except that the latter was actually a reasonable thing until about 1981 (when non-8-bit bytes became extinct).

Anyway, I'm not arguing for using "unsigned" in this PR, because I want to make progress, but, for the record, that's what it *should* be.

@cabo I appreciate your flexibility.

A couple of things bothered me about using "unsigned":
* In JSONPath we are dealing with integers represented as strings rather than values of a numeric type.
* If we (and I hope we don't!) allowed indices such as "-0" and "+5", it would seem strange to describe these as "unsigned".

@cabo I enjoyed your entertaining nostalgic review of integer types.

@glyn I am not aware of the fact, that in JSONPath we are dealing with integers represented as strings exclusively.

We have two kinds of integers:

1. those coming from the JSON data item.  These are no longer in text form when we get to them; they are true numbers (not necessarily type-annotated to be integers).
2. those written in the JSONPath query.  I would expect that our processing model parses that query and feeds an AST to the process that already has true integers etc. as well.  But we haven't fully defined the processing model, so that is next.
(I moved nodelist over to a new PR that I'm preparing.)

> I'm not sure whether it makes sense to start a JSONPath with a current item selector as this is not "in the middle of" an array selection, for example, so what would the current item even mean?
> 
The "current node" would mean the same thing as it means [in JMESPath](https://jmespath.org/specification.html#current-node), where it is clearly defined. At the start of JSONPath evaluation, it is the JSON document itself, what else could it be? As the expression is evaluated, the value that the current node represents changes to reflect the node currently being evaluated.  Given an `?(<expr>)` within `[]`, the processing model requires an iteration over the elements of the then current item (say an array); the expression following the "?" is evaluated with each of those elements, and an `@` appearing in that expression is substituted for with those elements.

In other words, at the start of JSONPath evaluation, `$` and `@` represent the same node. As evaluation proceeds, `$` stays the same, but `@` changes to reflect the node being evaluated.

> ... but @ changes to reflect the node being evaluated.

"... but `@` changes to reflect the _current scope_.

> The "current node" would mean the same thing as it means [in JMESPath](https://jmespath.org/specification.html#current-node), where it is clearly defined. At the start of JSONPath evaluation, it is the JSON document itself, what else could it be?

That seems to contradict the wording of this PR:
> The current item selector `@` when used outside a filter behaves as the document
root selector unless a child node is given to the evaluator.
When a child node is used as current item, evaluator must select it as starting
node instead of the document root when an expression starting with `@` is
evaluated.

I'll make an example for the benefit of this conversation, I rather discuss any disagreement comment about this feature on issue #59, so we just keep the conversation about pros/cons in just one place, and here we can just discuss the wording for what we decide at #59.

Let's assume the following eval function:
```
json_path_eval(document_root, path)
```

this implementation will always eval `@.foo` in the same way as `$.foo` as kindly mentioned by @danielaparker in previous comment.

any implementation might also augment the API by adding an additional (optional) parameter (an overload, or whatever the language supports):
```
json_path_eval(document_root, current_item, path)
```

therefore `@.foo` evals to `current_item.foo`, while `$.foo` evals to `document_root.foo` (an example is provided [here](https://github.com/ietf-wg-jsonpath/draft-ietf-jsonpath-jsonpath/issues/59#issuecomment-797116919) ).

It is up to the API user to decide to use current_item instead of the document root (@gregsdennis explained it well [here](https://github.com/ietf-wg-jsonpath/draft-ietf-jsonpath-jsonpath/issues/59#issuecomment-797212814) ).

Clearly we shouldn't describe the json_path_eval API in our draft (the API is clearly implementation specific).
We just describe the syntax (which is already supported by a number of implementations) and we formalize that a child node can be optionally provided, and in that situation "When a child node is used as current item, evaluator must select it as starting node instead of the document root when an expression starting with @ is evaluated.".

When a current item/an explicit starting scope is not provided, "The current item selector @ when used outside a filter behaves as the document root selector"

An implementation that doesn't care can safely just assume that `@` = `$` unless when current scope is changed by filters.

This wording should enable tooling as described in #59.

Let me know if you have any advice about how to improve wording so we make sure that the behavior described in #59 is accurately described, in case there are no further objections about the wording let's resolve this conversation.

> > The "current node" would mean the same thing as it means [in JMESPath](https://jmespath.org/specification.html#current-node), where it is clearly defined. At the start of JSONPath evaluation, it is the JSON document itself, what else could it be?
> 
> That seems to contradict the wording of this PR:
>

I agree :-) And I prefer the [JMESPath specification wording](https://jmespath.org/specification.html#current-node). In the JMESPath wording, there is no "if it's used outside the filter it means this" or "if it's used inside the filter it means that". There is just one consistent meaning for the "current-node", represented by `@`, it means the node currently being evaluated.

The original [JSONPath article](https://goessner.net/articles/JsonPath/) doesn't say much about the current node, it uses `@` to represent it (referred to as "current object"),  and gives two examples:

```
$.store.book[(@.length-1)].title                   (1)

$.store.book[?(@.price < 10)].title               (2)
```
Both of those examples are fully consistent with the JMESPath wording. In (1), the "current node" @ represents the array `$.store.book`, in (2), the `?` connotes iteration over the array, and `@` represents the array element.

It's easy to generalize that at `$`, the current node `@` represents '$', at `$.store`, it represents `$.store`, and so on.

> > ... but @ changes to reflect the node being evaluated.
> 
> "... but `@` changes to reflect the _current scope_.

See my reply to Glyn. I prefer the [JMESPath specification wording](https://jmespath.org/specification.html#current-node), which is very clear, and completely justifies paths that start with `@`.  Also see [here](https://github.com/ietf-wg-jsonpath/draft-ietf-jsonpath-jsonpath/issues/59#issuecomment-803618374) for more elaboration.
Added a reminder [here](https://github.com/ietf-wg-jsonpath/draft-ietf-jsonpath-jsonpath/issues/17#issuecomment-803584276), I'm resolving this conversation.

Resolves #84

## Alterations

- Removed `Object`, and `Array` since they are defined in 8259.  Replaced with extended verbiage at the beginning of the section that declares that 8259 applies.
- Replaced "JSON value" with "value" in line with the above.
- Relabeled "output path" as "normalized path"

## Additions

- String - a clarification and expansion on the JSON definition
- Root Node

## Other

- Reordered terms and paragraphs so that reading through doesn't use terms that haven't been defined yet (as much as possible).
- Removed a redundant parenthetical sentence in the *Processing Model* section.
- Removed some un-necessary self-references (e.g. "JSONPath query" rather than just "query").
- Made some general edits

## Notes

### Existing in-place definitions

"Selector" and "slice" are defined in-place where they're needed.  Do we need to define them in the terminology section as well?

### Key

The draft currently uses "name" instead of "key" as we had agreed in the meeting.  I suspect that this is because 8259 uses "name."  Since we're trying to align with that, I've left in "name."

### Index

We discussed using "index" as a generic term for either a numeric index for arrays or a name for objects.  However in editing this section, I'm starting to second-guess that decision.

Given that we've opted to define a union selector as taking as arguments "indices," "slices," and/or "filters," I don't think it's too much of a stretch to separately include "indices" and "names."  Because of this, I left the definition of "index" as is.

This also addresses the tendency to associate "index" with arrays, as @glyn had mentioned.

I'm leaving the changes to "union selector" to include all of the various things it can accept for another PR as this is solely to clean up terminology.

### Emphasizing terms

I tried capitalizing defined terms to emphasize their special meaning.  It got weird to read, though, since they're used so frequently.  Maybe not _every_ instance of the terms needs to be emphasized.  I'm not sure.  Happy to discuss.

I've left this change out for now, but there are definitely inconsistencies present already.

comments.body:
I find the definitions in 8259 rather confusing. Take _object_ for example. 8259 contains the following statements:
1. A JSON text is a serialized value.
2. `JSON-text = ws value ws`
3. A JSON value MUST be an object, array, number, or string, or one of the following three literal names: [...]
4. An object structure is represented as a pair of curly brackets surrounding zero or more name/value pairs (or members).

One way to read statement 1 is that a value is serlalized to produce JSON text and therefore a value is not itself in serial form. But statement 2 seems to imply that a value _is_ in serial form. So I think statement 1 has to be read as "A JSON text is a value in a serialized form."

If a value is in a serialized form, then statement 3 implies that an object is also in a serialized form.

But statement 4 is then confusing:
* It seems to be defining an object structure rather than an object.
* It's probably trying to define an object and say that an object is a structure (in the normal use of the word).
* It says an object (structure) "_is represented as_ a pair of curly brackets [...]", but if an object is a serialized thing, it _is_ a pair of curly brackets etc. (Or, perhaps better, an object _consists of_ a pair of curly brackets etc.)

I'm not sure whether we should attempt to clarify this in the JSONPath spec or submit an erratum to 8259 - probably the latter makes more sense.

comments.author: cabo
comments.body:
8259 is what it is.  It was created in a politically difficult situation, and it turned out better than many of us had feared.  But it is a rather poor document, and the errata process is not designed to fix its problems.

But the situation is actually worse.  When writing the JSONpath specification, we have to think about its audience and not about how we ourselves would like this document to be.  Most people who will read the JSONpath specification will come out of one of the JSON sub-ecosystems and will think that they know what JSON is.  They won't read 8259 just because we reference it.  It simply is not helpful to defer to 8259, we have to make sure that the terms we need are introduced properly.  (Not *defined* -- that is indeed what 8259 needs to be the authoritative reference for.). This is more important because the 8259 terminology is peculiar (its accidental or deliberate ambiguities served its purpose well in the painstaking 8259 process, but that doesn't mean it's particularly good for specifications that actually make use of JSON).

I wish we could focus on creating a good document for its audience, instead of discussing whether something theoretically needs to be brought up or not.

In fact the root node is not a node initially, as it lacks a name by nature. Similar to your formulation, the root node formally becomes a node by always getting the name '$' assigned by convention. 

Your formulation

`... refer to the root node of the argument`

somehow contradicts your comment

`The root node is by definition the entire argument.` 

and also somehow confuses below  by ...

`... executed against a value, the *argument* ...`

BTW the definition above  is cristal clear, as the *argument* is the value of the *root node*.

I think we agree with the following ...

* JSONPath is *selecting* only, not *processing*.
* Analytical post processing on the query result is heavily demanded by users.

I do like that brillant *extension points* concept a lot. So question is: Can we open the door for analytical post processing via those *extension points*? If so, the spec must provide certainty to implementors regarding *output path* format, which should be either/or ...

* list of selected values
* list of normalized pathes

So an *output path* always should have *normalized path* format in my opinion.

> So an output path always should have normalized path format in my opinion.

I'm not arguing this.  I'm questioning whether we need "output path" as an explicit definition.

To me, "output path" is just a normalized path that happens to be in the output.  There's nothing really special about it that requires a definition.  We _do_ need to define the output somewhere, but it's not a definition or term; it's a feature and requires its own section.

"Normalized path," on the other hand, is precisely what the current definition is describing:

> A simple form of JSONPath expression that identifies a node by providing a query that results in exactly that node.

> In fact the root node is not a node initially - @goessner 

Not quite.  "Argument" is already defined as a value (not a node):

```
Short name for the value a JSONPath expression is applied to.
```

This means that "entire value of the argument" is redundant.  My change simply removes the redundancy.  "Root node of the argument" identifies the top-level location of the initial JSON value.

For example, simply implementing the prescribed syntax would enforce that these characters are invalid.  The implementation can't (or probably shouldn't) coerce such a syntax error into the "index-selector" syntax.  It's up to the author of the Path to build a syntactically correct Path.

```suggestion
  * Root selector `$`
  * Dot selector `.<name>`, used with object member names exclusively.
  * Dot wild card selector `.*`.
  * Index selector `[<index>]`, where `<index>` is either an (possibly negative) array index or an object member name.
  * Index wild card selector `[*]`.
  * Array slice selector `[<start>:<end>:<step>]`, where `<start>`, `<end>`, `<step>` are integer literals.
  * Nested descendants selector `..`.
  * Union selector `[<sel1>,<sel2>,...,<selN>]`, holding a comma delimited list of selectors.
  * Filter selector `[?(<expr>)]`
  * Current item selector `@`
```

comments.body:
Proposal:
A Normalized Path is a JSONPath that uniquely identifies a node.

Perhaps something like "eineindeutig" in German.

Hmmm. Usually the word "unique" (and its variants) introduces confusion into specs. The questions it raises are:

* What thing is unique?
* What is the set of things among which the thing is unique?

In this context, "uniquely identifies a node" could be taken a couple of ways:

1. A Normalized Path is the only JSONPath (with certain characteristics) that identifies a particular node. This is true.
2. A Normalized Path identifies a unique node. This is not true if we are allowed to vary the JSON document.

As for "eineindeutig", I understand this to refer to the mathematical concept of a one-one correspondence. For a given JSON document, there is indeed a one-one correspondence between its nodes and the Normalized Paths that identify these nodes. But the above proposal doesn't talk about a given JSON document, in which case the one-one correspondence doesn't make much sense.

I think we need an informal definition of Normalized Path so readers have a chance of engaging. We could follow it up with some more text along the lines of:

> For a given JSON document,  there is a one to one correspondence between the document's nodes and the Normalized Paths that identify these nodes.

pulls.title: Singular paths
pulls.author: glyn
pulls.body:
Introduce the term Singular Path.

Restrict paths in filter expressions to be Singular Paths so that,
for instance, existence tests and the left and right side of comparisons
do not involve more than one node.

Ref: https://github.com/ietf-wg-jsonpath/draft-ietf-jsonpath-base/issues/155

Note though that JSONPath implementations divide into (1) those that use JavaScript, Python, PHP for expressions, and (2) those that invented their own expression language. Considering only the second group, you'll find that the important ones including Jayway allow expressions starting with `@` to be full JSONPath expressions in their own right, and that the result of evaluating these JSONPath expressions within filter expressions are _not_ result lists, rather, they are single values that are resolved according to well defined rules.
